clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Expressive Writing in Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Expressive Writing in Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test whether disease-related expressive writing is effective in the treatment of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).

detailed_description.textblock: Expressive writing involves writing about traumatic, stressful or emotional events. Expressive writing, for as little as 3-5 sessions of 20 minutes, has been found to improve both physical and psychological health based on health outcome measures such as number of doctor's visits and hospital days, blood pressure control, lung and immune function, and pain. Given its simplicity, and obvious advantages in terms of cost efficiency, expressive writing appears to have great potential as a therapeutic tool or as a means of self-help, either alone or as an adjunct to traditional therapies. This modality has not been studied in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a common gastrointestinal condition, which is lacking well-defined etiology or treatments and is best understood in a biopsychosocial context.

primary_outcome.description: IBSQOL is a measure of IBS - specific quality of life.

secondary_outcome.description: Measure of health-related cognition (catastrophizing or maladaptive coping,and patients' perceived ability to control symptoms)
HCU is a measure of frequency and type of health care received for IBS
IBSSS provides a disease severity measure

secondary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Scale for Functional Bowel Disorders (CGFBD)

secondary_outcome.description: The WEQ measure obtains subjects' reflections about their writing experience.

arm_group.description: Subjects in the Intervention were instructed to write for 30-minute intervals for 4 consecutive days about their deepest thoughts and feelings related to their Irritable Bowel Syndrome.

The participants were instructed to write for 30-minute intervals for 4 consecutive days about all of the actions they performed that day for a 24 hour period. The subjects were asked not to write about their feelings or thoughts related to these actions.
Subjects in this group did not receive an intervention. They filled out measures at baseline, 1 month, and 3 month follow-up time periods.

intervention.description: Subjects in the Intervention were instructed to write for 30-minute intervals for 4 consecutive days about their deepest thoughts and feelings related to their Irritable Bowel Syndrome.
Subjects were asked to write about the actions they performed during the last 24 hours. They were asked not to write about their feelings or thoughts related to these actions.
